posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Yeah I have 15 consoles in total right now and they're all ready to play simultaneously using 5 power strips daisy chained together with switches on each outlet, and all the inputs are handled by a system consisting of a component switcher, two composite/s-video switchers, two HDMI switchers, and a LAN hub. The analog switchers have dual outputs allowing me to play those games on either my CRT or my HDTV. While my HDTV has analog inputs I want to get an upscaler at some point because I also have an HDMI cable reaching from my PC to my TV stand so I can either display my PC on my TV or record my consoles using my capture card, but I can't do that with any of my retro consoles yet.

You don't. There is zero reason you can't organize the cables and inputs in a way where you can "hook up" whatever system you intend to play in under 3 minutes. All while NOT leaving the power and component cables in a nest behind some 'tb stand'

If you are too good at taking and defending your turf, the game punishes you by taking away any challengers. You have to leave at least one territory for each opposing gang if you want to be able to defend or invade turf again later. Can be somewhat fixed by glitching the game to create turf all over the map, but it's a half-assed solution.

>>9608448
Okay, let's start at the end(?), GTA III is the only game that "really" happened 1:1, in real-time.
Vice City Stories is Lance's recollection of his brother and his adventures when the two first arrived in Vice City, maybe it's survivor's guilt, but Lance puts Vic on a pedestal, hence why Vic practically babysits Lance the whole game.
Vice City is a movie by Tommy Vercetti showing his rise to power, more or less, decide for yourself what mission threads are in the movie and what had to be taken out for time.
San Andreas, okay you're gonna have to just keep up with me on this because this is REALLY autistic, Carl is a small-time criminal from LS, goes to LC, and comes back to LS, everything up until the Desert actually happens, Carl DID buy the air field, but the only mission that really happens is N.O.E where you have to drop supplies off on the other side of the map, everything else is a dehydration hallucination because Carl's too stupid to hydrate while watching flight videos and spy movies, The Truth missions are Carl and the Truth tripping out on Peyote in the desert, talking while Truth tells Carl about all the stuff he knows, the game picks back up with reality when Woozie calls Carl and tells him about Las Venturas, the two become partners Carl saves Madd Dogg and that's how CJ became a success, Toreno was grateful for CJ not only taking down the Loco Syndicate and delivering those supplies, and Sweet is miraculously let go.
LCS is another game that happened in real-time but it's not 1:1, some parts are more embellished, and could be chalked up to dreams and Tony leaving the TV on after a hard day.
Manhunt is a MSNBC documentary/news story, spliced in with snuff films because some high schooler wanted to be edgy, taped over, as we all know a Children's Show about a robochef.
Bully is Jimmy's story about Bullworth, some things like busting people out of asylums never happened, but to spark interest to the audience is sprinkled throughout the story.

I think what brings me to older games is that I have a sorta fascination with the material of games, and that is more visible in older games (sorta like the difference between novels and poetry). What I find beautiful isnt the beating of the game, what I find beautiful is the discovery of the seams. Figuring out how exactly they got NPCs to move a certain way, or seeing what decisions were made to make the world feel more alive. I dont think that the idea of being "lost in the magic" and seeing the scenes are mutually exclusive. Sorta like how going on the Universal Studios backlot tour makes you appreciate movie trickery more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm playing Phantasy Star 1, I didn't know how tough it was to navigate its 3D dungeons. I thought I've seen it all after I beat PS2, but this is somehow harder.
Every single wall looks the same, there's almost no way to tell where you are, or even where you were—every chest vanishes when you open it. And no, you don't even have items to instantly quit a dungeon up until certain point. Of course, I do draw maps for the dungeons, but I still got lost in a maze once and it was pretty terrifying—I thought I'd have to reset because there was literally no way I could tell where to go. Stumbled upon an exit just by pure luck.
Not only that, there are now also invisible fucking holes in some places, which drop you down a floor, and worst of all, fake walls which look exactly like real ones, but you can go through them. How the fuck are you supposed to know where they are?
Do you just have to map every step on a graph paper? Do other 1st person RPGs have similarly hard mazes, or do they at least add some distinction between different areas / rooms / etc or ways to see where you've already been?
On a side, I gave this game some shit initially, but it does get a bit better. The start is stupidly grindy though, it was worse than even DQ1.

>what the fuck is up with kojima
He never lost his touch or went from prophet to dogshit-peddler. He is and always has been a huge fucking nerd who had just enough insight to observe societal/cultural trends and wrote them into a wacky kabuki drama using the military industrial complex as a backdrop. Fukushima is an urban legend; someone who secretly made Metal Gear good wouldn't just drop off the face of the earth with no other notable writing credits to their name.
MGS1 through to V are all as thematically profound as each other, but the themes vary wildly in subject because the series spans 30 fucking years. The writing "quality" for the games of his which you hold in high regard is solely down to Jeremy Blaustein and Agness Kaku's localization work, since MGS2 was the last time there was a dedicated localization writer on board.
You used to put Kojima on a pedestal because his earlier work was forced to be more restrained by technical limitations and cultural divides, and when he had the means to express his ridiculous vision more clearly, you realized you couldn't stomach it after all.

>>9611264
Today I am officially starting /vr/'s first Serious Sam mapping project called "A Serious Case Of /vr/"
If you're new to mapping with SED1 then check out this quick start guide: https://rentry.org/vy4qr

A Serious Case of /vr/ Rules:
>Map must be made for Serious Sam The Second Encounter 1.07 version (this is the most up to date retail version on Steam/GOG)
>Usage of custom textures, sounds, and music is approved and encouraged
>Usage of custom entities or other mods is NOT allowed. Outside of textures, sounds, and music your map should be 100% vanilla with 1.07
>Please provide a readme listing your name (even if it's anonymous), map name, and sources for any custom content used
>Map must be beatable and have proper co-op support
>Do not make edits of existing maps
>Project host has the final say and can deny your entry if it is not up to /vr/ "standards" (please put some effort into your map)
>Rules are subject to change
>Deadline: TBD

Tips:
>Trigger a checkpoint whenever a new weapon is picked up to ensure everyone spawns with an up-to-date arsenal
>Make co-op portals for arenas that get closed off (and/or one-way doors so players don't get trapped)
>Aim to balance your map around Serious difficulty first, but don't be afraid to make support for other difficulties later
>Try to keep co-op in mind when balancing fights, drawn out reinforcement spawners are not fun to wait on
>Hot starts are not that common in Serious Sam, make a "lobby" for players to jump around in without risk of triggering anything (useful for co-op)
>A good fight is more enjoyable than a good looking room, don't stress yourself out over brushwork
>Use the official maps as references (I won't berate you for coping models, texture work, etc. from official maps) (You can have multiple maps open at the same time and switch between them on the fly in the editor)
>Don't forget to make a thumbnail for your level
>Ask questions if you need help
>Get creative with secrets!

Because the dev made basically made every wrong decision and the resulting game is simply not fun to play:
1. He spent great deal of time crunching numbers to ensure balance - but forgot to make gameplay actually fun
2. Focused on co-op multiplayer too much - even though it's not a Zandronum game
3. Giant, boring levels that you constantly have to go through
4. Couldn't keep it in his pants. Usually people are willing to overlook one weird fetish, but not two at once. If it was just bara men, or just furries, it would've been fine, but bara furries is over the line. The point of fanservice is to attract potential players, not to alienate them.

This game is extremely educational, it should be studied by any fledgling game designer, you can write long essays on what went wrong with it.

>>9612371
I decided to dig through the past few threads to get some numbers. Counting the amount of posts explicitly pertaining to SRB2K in each thread led me to these results
>25 posts of 527 last thread, about 4.7%
>20 posts of 588 before that, about 3.4%
>14 posts of 602 in the thread preceding that, about 2.3%
>Said posts are frequently about creating content (i.e. Sprites) for the game
>Said posts are also usually screenshots with little text content, doesn't take up much screen space
Going by the past three threads, SRB2K related content makes up less than 5% of posts in these threads. Said posts are so minimal that anyone not interested can easily scroll past them, even the long ones because 2000 characters is not a lot. That leaves the only argument being "it's not an FPS," but it is a mod of Doom, which is explicitly covered in the OP, reading
>Gameplay, WADs/Maps/Mods, Source Ports
(The game also has a first person view option, and you shoot people with various items, so there's that too)

In short, you're complaining about content that makes up a fraction of the threads, is easily avoidable, is infrequent to other games in comparison, harmless by 4chan standards, and is thread relevant.
Welcome to 4chan. If you don't like certain content, ignore it. If you think content is harmful, counteract it by posting content you like instead of complaining without substance.
tl;dr SRB2K is fun and on-topic, fuck off

>>9612858
>less than 5% of posts
That's equivalent to rolling a Nat 1 on a d20. I can see how some people would get butthurt about those odds, especially when it beats some unquestionably relevant series' representation, like Unreal, Heretic/Hexen, and even Serious Sam on an average day.
Of course, that can be blamed just as much on people not talking about those games as often as things like Doom, Quake, and even Blood or Duke3D (let alone SRB2K), but I still think it's valid to draw attention to SRB2K's possible overrepresentation.
Personally, I think that it being a Sonic fangame made in a retro Doom source port (assuming Doom Legacy is still the foundation of SRB2K; I wouldn't know to be honest) is reason enough to allow it. If SRB2 would be on-topic, SRB2K should be, too.

Doom wad generation is still limited as is and people thinking most custom wads are just slaughter wads will not take away the more interesting and unique wads away

>Any chance it has source ports like Doom?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9615090
Just get the max pack from gog, its a pre-setup dosbox.
The win95 version is better, but not as stable. I don't think multiplayer is very important for you, so that shouldn't matter.

Carma 2 has some music issues, a basic fix is just renaming carma2_hw.exe to anything else and it should work, but it will crash everytime you quit.
The better solution is downloading _inmm.dll (a program used to get certain older implementations of audio to work), specifically https://community.pcgamingwiki.com/files/file/107-patched-_inmmdll. It contains some extra for variables carma2 (and many other games), install it.
You patch Carma2_hw.exe by just dragging it onto inmmcnf.exe (or its shortcut name _inmm.dll setup).
You then open inmmcnf.exe normally and add *.ogg (that's what the files should be) to the filetypes and set player to DirectShow (same for the default just in case).
You then go to the _inmm.ini tab and add the songs either via the button or dragging them on the list and then saving. You put the .ini it wants to save in the folder with the executable. Don't move the music folder as it points to that.

its always a larger hassle to write out _inmm instructions than actually doing it as its quite simple.

Are you telling me that Snakes Revenge is not a sequel to Metal Gear on the NES? Yeah, I get it. Snake didn't exactly destroy Metal Gear in the NES game. But did the developers remember? The original Metal Gear was never released on any platform in English, and the only western port was the NES game. Which is the Metal Gear game that most get nostalgic for. The NES game sold like as million units, and Snakes Revenge was a NES exclusive sequel made by one of the Konami console teams. So, when Metal Gear Solid was announced, a lot of the western hype came from people familiar with the NES Metal Gear games. Metal Gear Solid does have a recap for the first and second MSX games, and most people probably thought Metal Gear 2 was referring to the NES game; Snakes Revenge. You can buy the MSX games now on GOG and steam and other digital services. But back in the day, they were obscure outside of Japan. But the NES games were not.

>>9583547
NTA, but.
Point-and-click game with copious CGI, impressive production values, batshit insane plot, full voice acting, and it impressed Nintendo so much they hired a lot of the staff for their EAD team. It's Japan-only, for the moment being. Only times it got talked about before was when collector hoarders accidentally leaked a private mega folder with tons of games including this previously lost game.
Company did 3 games like these and folded shortly after. Supposedly uses a Macromedia type thing.

Some copyright troll trademarked a bunch of stuff including the logo for the game and took down most of the media about it online, and it looks more like erasing the game from existence than a prospective new release. Nearly nothing is left online.

The game is about a 5 year old American girl identifying as a bear (and portrayed as such) going to dangerous locations after hearing voices in her head. The game opens with her being refused a bus ride, that bus is bombed by terrorists and everyone is dead, the terrorists are gunned by an airplane and everyone is dead, and the girl inspects the bus and goes "It can't be helped". Then she has to avoid dying by starvation, getting hugged to death by a pedophile cop, getting killed in the crossfire of other terrorists in a public park where a schizophrenic woman thinks the heroine is daughter, and then an alien locale that defies description. I'm saddened the walkthrough was taken offline. I really want to see how this goes now that I learned more Japanese. The backstory intro roll itself (which is in English) alone is a riot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9596951
>>9596953
Anon who posted that. It's still the original files, but they are preinstalled on an emulated Windows 98 Machine so the game is easy to play

The ISO file is in a folder titled 'Files' along with the Windows 98 drive, and is mounted to the machine so the game can run, but is also there to make it easier to use and explore compared to the format of the original files

To run the machine, run "Launch.bat" in the folder

>qemu-system-i386 -nodefaults -rtc base=localtime -display sdl -L pc-bios -m 256 -machine pc,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off -device VGA -device lsi -device sb16 -drive file=Files/w98.qcw -cdrom Files/CB1_DISC.iso -boot c

Its just a one line command that launches the machine with the correct settings, but I obviously get not wanting to run some random batch script and exe, so you can also move the files to your own qemu install and it'll work fine

>>9600572
Not much, but there are two things you can try that may help.

First is to change '256' to '512' to increase the amount of memory the machine has, though I don't know if this will really help.

The other, if you are on Windows and have the Windows Hypervisor Platform enabled, is to change this
>-machine pc,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off
to this
>-machine pc,accel=whpx,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off
which will improve the general performance through virtualization

This can cause some issues related to shutting down the emulated machine though, but its nothing major

I'd like to report that it runs on Wine 7.0.1 pretty much out of the box.

You actually can run Wine on Windows by using WSL2. That way you're still using a VM, but it'll be a sensibly fast one (modern Windows hosting a modern Linux guest) rather than a bug-ridden one (modern Windows trying to run a Win 98 guest).
Just download the "Ubuntu" app from your Windows Store and then `sudo apt install wine` and hey presto you've got Wine.

For anons who are suffering from bad sound running the Windows 98 QEMU VM, it's probably due to QEMU's poorly emulated SoundBlaster sound card.
In comparison the AC97 codec is much more open and accurately emulated.
To try that, change "-device sb16" to "-device ac97".
Then you'll need to install the driver. One possibility to to search for the "SigmaTel C-Major Audio AC97 WDM driver".

>>9604896
Good or not depends on if you like point-and-clicks. As for interesting, yes. It's a pretty high level of Japanese weirdness with pretty good (for 1999 PC games) production values.

It's about a 5 year old girl from New Jersey named Cookie Blair who sees herself as a teddy bear, the intro gives the backstory that a century ago aliens arrived on an island in the South Pacific and made an agreement with the island's president where they could own a part of the land if they shared their technology with him. They eventually started an annual Olympics-like sports contest, which Cookie wants to enter.

The very first thing that happens in the game is Cookie loses her bus pass, the bus driver kicks her off the bus, and then as the bus drives away some people drive up in a jeep with a rocket launcher and blow up said bus... which causes a helicopter to arrive and blast away said people and then fly away. There is apparently an alternate version of that scene where the rocket people and helicopter blow each other up.

It's also possible to die in the crossfire of two gangs in the middle of the park, pick up a spirit radio that lets you hear (ghost?) sex, die from smoking, find Laura Croft's corpse in a tomb, win a dance-off, and break out of jail. I am sure there are dozens of other weird scenarios I haven't encountered.

It's pretty wacky.

Of course I mean inside qemu (more accurately inside Windows 98). WDM is the Windows 9x driver type, not NT (i.e. Win 10).

>>9606821
If you mean the audio cutting during cutscenes, I don't how to resolve that.

But if you mean the audio being distorted and stuttery, that can be fixed by disabling hardware acceleration on the sound output inside of Windows 98.

You can do this by going to the Control Panel, then 'Multimedia', and then selecting 'Advanced Properties' on the playback device. Then select 'Performance' at the top and use the slider to disable hardware acceleration.

This is caused using the ac97 instead of the sb16

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Repost from >>>/v/625694309

How you can help with a translation

Yes, we need someone fluent in Japanese, with the same skillset needed for translating audio dramas or anime (less than 40 minutes of audio).
The audio is extracted as individual files with filenames out of their context.
That translator would need to transcribe all of them to Japanese (to make later revisions easier) first.
Then give his/her own interpretation of the text in English second.

Audio files are already extracted, but not organized in a very friendly way.

>https://mega.nz/folder/IGcQ3CJa#P6VUlCjXAJxdoiZHgqBLMQ
Get this file
>Asset rips/Audio Dump WAV.zip
It has all ingame sfx, bgm and voice acting, except for the movies.
They're all short wav files named like this
>dirOpened output of nms-1683.wav

From what I noticed, they seem to be following this trend:
>nms
general voice acting (1683 files)
>sky, swm
minigame voice acting / sfx (43 files)
>cly, ffh, hdl
more minigame voice acting / sfx (74 files)
>acs
mostly sound effects and grunts and background music, but some are voice acting like acs-196 to acs-206 which cover saving/loading the game. better saved for last (216 files)

Same mega.nz folder has another file for the movies.
>Asset rips/Movies.zip
Only a handful have voice acting.
They can be hard subbed probably, but a transcription would be better even for stuff that's in voiced/written in Engrish because the audio quality is generally poor.

For the transcript to be useful it could be formatted this way:

>acs-200
>オープニングムービーを見る?
>Watch the opening movie?

as a text file, covering all of the game files.
If you don't want to type acs/nms every time you can just type the number and just clarify which section it is in the beginning of the file.

>acs-196 to acs-206
Those audio strings already have matching visual text in English even in the Japanese version.
So the acs files are low priority, but should be checked just in case.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9609140
>Dumping (and maybe recompiling) the game's scripting seems possible, but I'm not even sure if Director supports any kind of subtitles. Have to go dig through the old documentation.

>What we have now
All of the audio extracted from the cxt/cst files: Can be transcribed and given a text translation
All of the movies are in an easily editable format that can be hard subbed
All visual elements are already in English: Don't need a translation
Sprites and all of their individual animation frames are easily extracted in Macromedia editor from cxt/cst files

>How the project can move forward

>Dub route - easiest, but worst
The extracted audio can be replaced with English equivalents. Not that many voice actors. However, it would lose SOUL.
The videos can be redubbed or subtitled fairly easily like old documentary shows

>In-Engine Sub route - keeps compatibility with W95, but might be glitchy/not possible
New images are added through Macromedia editor for all possible voiced lines. English text on a transparent background.
The game logic in Macromedia Director needs to be deobfuscated (still not done yet), every single audio call will be changed to call those new textures, they'd appear for a fixed duration of time (length of the voiced line) and then disappear
Might be done via cxt/cst modding but unsure.

>Modern Enhancement Sub route - ideal, but hardest
The executable, a glorified Macromedia Director projector, is modded in IDA Pro to intercept any calls for audio playback and displays proper soft subtitles overlaid on top of the screen from an external srt file with proper timing data (might help with multi-line subtitles, and more importantly the subs are no longer held back by the engine limitations + multi language translations are possible) - of course an external text renderer might need to be coded but that's really easy
While you're at it, it could intercept mov playback and override them with AI upscaled versions of the movies

It has to do with the speed of the combat and how mobile the character is.

In something like Bayo or Ninja Gaiden you're so much more faster and agile that it wouldn't feel well. Zelda games and Maximo are much slower in combat and you move a lot less. There are sometimes inputs that use the 360 but between 2 different attack buttons, fast enough frame data to make use of pauses (eg A,A vs A,wait,A), and the many ways you can dial up an attack there is no reason to resort to these inputs which as I said are going to feel bad with how fast and agile these newer characters are.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
N64 was the "tech demo" phase for a lot of this stuff. Really showing up all of the different ways a character can control in a 3D space, and all of the different things you can do with an analogue stick in gameplay.

After that, we move into the stream-lining phase, where developers are thinking less about what the player "could" do, and thinking more about what most players are going to want, which is simplicity of controls and mechanics. That's either a good or a bad thing, depending on how you view it.

Seems like it was very common for an N64 game to have different movement speeds, climbing, swimming, crawling, ledge grappling, first person view modes, and flight all baked into the design, while a modern game like Elden Ring might not necessarily have even half of those options.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9594662
more options doesn't necessarily mean better. OoT was a very good start on 3D combat but right now I would say there are two game series that influence 3D action games the most: Devil May Cry and Dark Souls not retro though.

The prior focuses on giving the player as many combat options as possible and makes that the fun of the game. Launchers, flying attacks, guns, ways to combo enemies, parries, everything you could want to do. These games are more about being stylish than just outright winning the fight. However this limits the enemy design as these games can quickly become unfun if there's too many enemies you can't combo effectively, or if the bosses act in a way that's too limiting to your arsenal.

While the latter is the exact opposite, you have an extremely narrow set of options in combat. Block, dodge, light swing, heavy swing, shoot projectile and maybe a few more options. While this seems limiting it allows the developers to focus much more heavily on challenging enemy design based on how enemies respond and require you to use the few options in your arsenal. People generally love boss fights in these kind of games for this exact reason, every single boss is like learning a song in a rhythm game since its mostly been simplified to "when do I dodge and when do I hit?".

OoT has a lot of options that lack purpose. Yes you can angle your swipes, horizontally or vertically, but what value does that have over just hitting the B button? The answer is none because enemies don't respond to things in ways that warrant you to change that. Would crouch stabbing have any value if it wasn't just objectively the best DPS in the game? I don't think so, because no enemies have a mechanic where you need to crouch to evade their attacks. Dodge mechanics are hardly even necessary because only a tiny few enemies can threaten your shield, I can't even think of any other than Darknuts.

So I think that answers your question, quality > quantity.

I remember tearing apart my xbox 360 and cleaning out shitloads of cat hair and fixing the RROD. Even the radioshack employee who sold the thermal paste smugly asked me if I was doing that. It worked for a few more years until the video card melted.
Modding the original xbox is a great experience, if only for putting a huge hard drive on it and custom firmware. That thing is a monument to modern media players.
The PS2 has physical locks that you can bypass. The PSP with pandora batteries as well. The whole modchipping scene is now popular with Switch consoles. Now a freemcboot card can be bought easily and do everything you want.
I’ve heard of DJs modding game boy colors to output MIDI and using them as chiptune effects. It’s a very niche genre but I think people here can at least appreciate sounds from original hardware.
The PortableWii scene is interesting. Very interesting. There’s a whole world here to explore.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've done a bunch of mods. Here's a brief list:
Famicom composite (worthless*)
Mega drive 60Hz (worthless*)
Gameboy backlight/bivert (mediocre, lots of ghosting, angles are fucky)
GBA chink AGS-101 swap (great to look at, but holding a GBA isn't comfortable as an adult)
PS1 modchip (worthless*)
Dreamcast GD-emu, fan swap (great, although the fan swap needed some extra work)
N64 RGB mod (great)
Xbox 128mb swap (worthless, I wanted to play VC3 but there's no good way to get a lightgun working on it)
Switch joycon d-pad shell (inferior shiny plastic, but having a d-pad is too important. I use them in the grip anyway, so you barely notice it)

Softmods:
PS2 freeMCboot, HDD>SD adapter (great)
Xbox softmod (great)
Wii softmod (great)

All the worthless* are for mods that were superseded by MiSTer, at the time they were okay.

Buy a soldering iron (ideally one with temp control), buy one of those little copper wire cleaning balls, buy some solder. You're done, now go try and solder shit to and from random old crap you have lying around until you get the idea.

Several key parts in the MD aren't produced anymore and would have to be recreated.

>68000
Is not produced anymore, at least not in its original form (there is one weird embedded version still available but not a straight 68k)
>YM2612
Ditto
>VDP
The only bit of custom silicon. If the original schematics still exist it could be possible to reproduce the CMOS variant used in the Genesis 2 although not the NMOS VDP in the Model 1.

Anyway, I believe the good GOAC is the "TCT-6801" chip, EverDrives work with it and it (or clones of it) seems to be what's in most currently manufactured Genesis clones (that aren't emulators). HAMY, Columbus Circle, and Gamerztek are good brands to poke around with. You can get Gamerztek stuff on Amazon as they're a US company. Afaik they take the Chinese HAMY designs and "americanize" them a bit. Don't get me wrong, clone consoles are built top be dirt cheap, but they do work and frankly I think it's fucking awesome that you can still buy actual hardware of these machines, even if it's not as good as the originals.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xOrqBa6gfEw - Random video with some music. Most of the reviews of these devices are the worst of the worst z-tier eceleb youtube shills, so keep that in mind when searching.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9599906
70s-80s chips were often NMOS logic. This is when all the transistors in the chip are n-doped. It has the disadvantage of using a lot of power and getting hot as it forces every transistor in the chip to draw current even when idling, and it also produces a lot of signal line noise and can have glitchy behavior due to how the logic works.

All modern chips (anything designed in the last 30+ years) are CMOS logic, which is a mix of p and n-doped transistors. It is much more efficient and cooler running as idling transistors do not use any power and it's free of signal line noise and glitches. However it was not widely used for years as it was more complex to manufacture and early CMOS chips were very slow (solved when they found they could just thin the metallization layer). CMOS chips are less forgiving of sloppy system design as they can be damaged by a bus conflict as that will drive the signal lines on the chip high, while NMOS signal lines would go low.

I have made a musical discovery regarding an old favorite: The "drugstore" (weapons, items etc) music from Earthbound is modeled on "Maxwell's Silver Hammer", by The Beatles. Although they are musically distinct, they have a clear similarity:

-Both melodies are these happy, mid-tempo, plodding but slightly subversive things.
-The pitch goes jauntily up-and-down in both cases.
-the ending of each "verse" is unmistakably the same. Try singing "sure that she was dead" to the ending of the drugstore music before it repeats again (the drugstore take adds two beats after this)
-the developers were clearly into the Beatles, per an early in-game Onett joke.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mJag19WoAe0
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OOXFR5SQnYk

posts.com:
The fact that so many books still name the Beatles as "the greatest or most significant or most influential" rock band ever only tells you how far rock music still is from becoming a serious art. Jazz critics have long recognized that the greatest jazz musicians of all times are Duke Ellington and John Coltrane, who were not the most famous or richest or best sellers of their times, let alone of all times. Classical critics rank the highly controversial Beethoven over classical musicians who were highly popular in courts around Europe. Rock critics are still blinded by commercial success. The Beatles sold more than anyone else (not true, by the way), therefore they must have been the greatest. Jazz critics grow up listening to a lot of jazz music of the past, classical critics grow up listening to a lot of classical music of the past. Rock critics are often totally ignorant of the rock music of the past, they barely know the best sellers. No wonder they will think that the Beatles did anything worthy of being saved. In a sense, the Beatles are emblematic of the status of rock criticism as a whole: too much attention paid to commercial phenomena (be it grunge or U2) and too little to the merits of real musicians. If somebody composes the most divine music but no major label picks him up and sells him around the world, a lot of rock critics will ignore him. If a major label picks up a musician who is as stereotyped as can be but launches her or him worldwide, your average critic will waste rivers of ink on her or him. This is the sad status of rock criticism: rock critics are basically publicists working for major labels, distributors and record stores. They simply highlight what product the music business wants to make money from.

And you OP, you just do not understand how easy it is to "accidentally" copy rock music as it is all the same. Earthbound was not ifluenced by anything. It is just rock music being too simplistic.

Just my two cents.

>And what is your Crash opinion?
I agree with you in general. Crash 2 is the easiest to casually play and my favourite overall. It has the best secrets in the coloured gems; there are hints but the game never spells it out for you unlike the remake. There are just some oddities that get the noggin joggin and encourage you to try new things. Wonder why Turtle Woods has a single bounce crate on that crate wall? Why is it the only level where the box counter stays after I get the gem and say /0? Wonder if I could get through the level without breaking any boxes...

Crash 1 has the tightest level themeing; you're going on an adventure across the islands, gradually moving from nature to polluting industry and the levels reflect that. I fucking love that the silhouette of Cortex's castle can be seen from Sunset Vista.

Crash 3 is the most wacky and cartoony and high energy. It's fun, and the bosses are the best, but it loses the strong themeing that was in Crash 1 and to a lesser degree Crash 2. The powers are cool but break the game

>>9609283
crash 1 is clunky and brutal but still a great game and an interesting bridge between 2d and 3d design principles. It's also the most unique as 2 and 3 are much more alike and 1 is with any others.
crash 2 is where they honed the formula and nailed down how things like crystals and gems would work but they still made a bunch of bad design choices (jetpack levels, backtracking without being able to see shit) and have a bunch of recycled levels between warp rooms that let it down..
3 is where classic crash reached its peak, the bosses didn't suck for the first time in the series and the powerups and relics made it feel much more complete, but also upped the gimmick levels as they were running out of ideas. Still no gimmick/vehicle levels as bad as the jetpacks in 2 though.
Overall 3>1>2

>>9608881
>get off the boat
>enter Census Office
>draft up a class with the skills and attributes I wanna focus on
>then as soon as I can, go and open my inventory by the shelves and the tables and steal everything which isn't nailed down
>immediately drop it all on the floor before closing the menu
>that way the guard can't confiscate my stolen goods when he runs over to me
>then when I've taken everything and dropped it on the ground, I'm free to pick it back up again and leave with it
>including that nice and expensive Dwarven Limeware Platter
>close the door behind me so I can take everything else in peace
>make sure to get Fargoth's ring
>hawk all of this shit at Arrille's trade house (he likes me since I got Fargoth's ring back, giving me better prices)
>pick out the best gear he has for me and then trade and haggle shit, juggling wares back and forth to maximize my profits
>go find the taxman's body
>take off his pants and put them on because they're nicer than mine
>go to Foryn Gilnith's shack
>confront and kill him
>take the taxman's expensive ring
>take everything that isn't nailed down as well as his clothes
>collect cash reward at Census Office (he gives you more if you find the body and kill Gilnith before telling him)
>collect potions in exchange for expensive ring from taxman's widow
>do Hriskar's quest to collect Fargoth's debt from his stash, so I can steal his money and his ring
>go raid the slaver's cave
>go raid the tomb down the shoreline for Mentor's Ring, hoping to avoid catching Ghost Herpes from a bonewalker
>use Gilnith's shack to store shit until I can find a nicer place elsewhere
>take a nap to kill a Dark Brotherhood hitman, so I can juggle goods with their valuable armor at the tradehouse for even more cash
For whatever reason, I fucking love murderhobo'ing the shit out of Seyda Neen at the start of the game as to extract as much wealth as possible out of the place, even if I then play it more reserved later.

>>9608881
Well... Like clockwork I....

Rob the key for the seyda neen warehouse; sell everything that I could get my pays on from the census office, do the quest for the dead tax man. AND MAYBE steal fargoths shit. I give him his ring back because it sucks.

I acquire some summon skele scrolls and open door scrolls from Arille before I'm off to Balmora . I usually join the balmora mage's guild regardless of characters type and do ajira's first few quests so I can steal most of Galdriel (Is that her name?) soul gems and shit. Then I'm off to Caldera. I kill every orc in Ghorak Manor and that shit becomes my house.From here is when I usually decide what direction I want to take my character. In this last playthrough I joined the Morag Tong for legitimately the first time ever. And I love it. Acquiring certain key spells for use and enchanting. Boosting alchemy potions. (Fortify Intelligence>Feather>Speed> Restore Health/Magicka)... part 1

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9610959
Part 2; now it's just some personal character stuff that I'll add.

I almost always enchant some Equisite Rings and Amulets with 100 Absorb Health on Target. Name it some shit like "Take Life" or "Vampire's Kiss/Embrace" Damage Health is Fun too just because it feels sinister.

Usually Enchant Feather onto my clothes and shit. ( Console command magicka regen fix. I now have 1hp 1mp regeneration at all times. Anything more than this really breaks the game and even this is pretty game breaking.)

With my Feather potions from earlier, I can carry an extra 200-300 pounds at any time as I am a bit of a hoarder. and HATE leaving cool shit behind.

I also decorate every house. Usually with some candles and lanterns and shit cuz it's so dark sometimes.

Create Duplicate summon spells so I can have a host of bonelords and shit with me in a big fight.

Choose a great house, nail the main quest or something.

Once I find a NPC "Travel Together" Quest I clone them with the "placeatpc" command. I then BUMP their stats like crazy because the A.I. can get itself killed so often. I like to deck them out in the same armor I have. See pic below of my latest follower, made a clone of the zainab slave that you convince the war chief is a telvanni bride. I played with the scale command and turned her into a loli for a little bit XD

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9610979
Some Enchanter will eventually randomly have a "Scroll of Windwalker" or "Scroll of Windform" And they will always have one scroll you go back into the barter menu. Collect about 200 of these scrolls at a time. They make traveling a HELLUVA lot simpler and safer.

Soultrap every single Dagoth " " creature into a grand soul gem.

Often Times I'll RP the nerevarine aspect kind of hard and usually will kill and soul trap Vivec. And resurrect him MANY times with console commands due to the fact that his soul has the most value in the game for enchanting. Or kill him once and dupe the Grand Soul Gem I stuff him in many times with console commands. (Yes you can dupe unique enchants, very cool)


From there on it's mostly RP driven for me depending on the type of character I am playing. I ironically don't think I've ever done a full on fighter character; but it's next on my bucket list.

I legit only recently realized you could copy/clone NPCS. So now I can put the best Enchanters/smiths/travel npcs into a building/buildings of my choice.

I'm currently doing a kind of Honorable Sith Lord thing where I plan on heading the Morag Tong, Become house master of Hlaalu and plan on taking over the Cammona Tong. in Tandem with Swathes of the Main Quest. I often become a vampire but am not sure about it on this play through. Werewolves are fun too.

Kill Every SLEEPER NPC for daring to bother me. Master speech skills so i can taunt anyone into attacking first.

The fact that with the Morag Tong; some NPCs will NOT conversate with you unless you get fully naked. I turned it into a wierd sociopathic tradition with my writ targets. Can only imagine what the npcs around think watching this cute little Breton whore undress and then murder. They can't do shit because writs are Legal.

I eventually end up having several houses for several purpose's and storage. Is it "Neloth's" house next to ghorak manor with the underground spooky cellar? Mine now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Flashing bootleg GBA cartridges with a GC to GBA link cable and a PC or softmodded GC or Wii can be accomplished by following the steps below.

Required materials:

- GC to GBA Link Cable
- PC with a serial port
- Softmodded GameCube or Wii
- Flash cartridge
- EZ-Flash IV Flash Kit

Step 1: Connect the GC to GBA link cable to the GBA cartridge, and the GameCube or Wii.

Step 2: Connect the other end of the GC to GBA link cable to the PC with a serial port.

Step 3: Download the EZ-Flash IV Flash Kit from the EZ-Flash website.

Step 4: Install the EZ-Flash IV Flash Kit on the PC.

Step 5: Launch the EZ-Flash IV program, and select the “Flash Cartridge” option.

Step 6: Select the “GC-GBA Link” option, and then choose the “Start” button.

Step 7: On the GC or Wii, press the “Link” button.

Step 8: On the PC, the EZ-Flash IV program will now detect the GBA cartridge, and will begin to flash the cartridge.

Step 9: When the flashing process is complete, press the “Finish” button to exit the EZ-Flash IV program.

Step 10: Disconnect the GC to GBA link cable from the PC, and the GameCube or Wii.

Once these steps have been completed, you will have successfully flashed a bootleg GBA cartridge with a GC to GBA link cable and a PC or softmodded GC or Wii.

With a DS you can dump ROMs from a cart (genuine or bootleg), dump save files (genuine carts and SOME bootleg ones) and inject save files into the cart (original carts only).

You're a fucking retard. It's called "practice". "Practice" is getting better at a game's mechanics until you master it and are ready to react to and tackle anything the game throws at you. Practice is going to the batting cages and getting good at hitting any kind of throw.

>That anon isn't wrong at all to say that there is technically grinding in every game.
Yes he (you) is (are), you fucking autist. Any official definition of "grinding in video games" is going to relate it to RPGs, because there is a fundamental difference between grinding to increase a character's stats so he doesn't get killed in one hit by a boss, and """grinding""" to increase the player's actual real life skill at a game's mechanics.

But that's irrelevant to the point anyway. Let's say, for the sake of argument, we consider "grinding" in other games. Take a game like Zelda. This game is not an RPG. But if you want to buy a certain item from a shop, you will need Rupees. You COULD spend an eternity killing enemies to get enough Rupees to grab it, and that could be called "grinding" but theoretically, you don't need to do that at all. Nothing in the game requires you to grind, you can easily get enough Rupees to buy whatever you need, by the time you need it, by just playing the game normally.

That's not the same as Final Fantasy II asking you to get yourself hit a bunch of times to build up your defense to a respectable level.

posts.com: When it comes to video games and computers, ignoring the additions that were done by the British would be a great mistake. However, once you hit about the mid-90s, the British just fall off the map. They fall off in computer technology, video games, even music. What happened to make the output of the British greatly diminish? Was it the adoption of the IBM computer that did it? Did the government used to support projects, and then stop? This isn't a political thread, by the way, I'm only curious what happened to stop the large output of content.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The real problem was the downfall of BASIC, which used to be a nearly universal lingua franca for every computer out there and as long as you relegated yourself to using the more or less universally implemented subset of functions you could be a full bore user developer and write software that would run on most any computer in existence, from University time-sharing systems to personal computers. Sure the OS makers and professional software writers would use a different language most of the time but countless small software businesses flourished and hobbyists themselves produced a shitload of software too.

Once BASIC went away and the industry started moving toward expensive proprietary toolkits with ever-shifting OS and dev stacks it was all over for the hobbyist industry because programming became much more complicated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9614528
It's a complicated matter, but from what I understand, the British industry had been declining since the late 60s or the early 70s. As the result of nationalist and supply and demand economic policies, there was little incentive to invest on manufacturing tools and improving labour skills. Manufacturing cost was expensive compared to their competitors, so most of the British wealthy chose to invest in the service sector. Politicians like Callaghan tried to push back against this shift and make British manufacturing competitive again by taxing the service sector, limiting pay raises and such, but it was met with heavy pushback which led to what was known as "Winter of Discontent". Thus, Thatcher was elected, and she deregulated the market while pursuing a monetarist policy that hurt British exports. Trade unions were seen to be a scary and powerful that threatened the crumbling British industry back then, but Thatcher's policy to remove their bargaining power altogether was proved even more detrimental to the industry

TL;DR manufacturing lost, finance won. They couldn't keep up with the rapid pace of the Japanese and German industry, and those who tried to save it did a few blunders that caused a pushback. Ultimately, most of the western world was flirting with neoliberal policies that reduced the power of their industrial sector as manufacturing jobs and tools were sent over to the eastern world for maximum profits, but Britain certainly doubled down on it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The answer is globalism. Most British developers were not interested in becoming part of massive mega corps and wanted to continue making the quirky and unusual games they enjoyed. However, the rise of games consoles meant you were forced to play by the rules of the likes of Nintendo, and the ability to cheaply mass produce disks was replaced with massive loyalty charges to create cartridges only allowed at high volumes.
Most of the British developers and publishers got destroyed by this, one single failure meant the death of a company, and Japanese and American megacorps eagerly scooped up all the talent and took them abroad.
This caused a massive braindrain.

There actually is still a pretty big British games industry now (they absolutely dominate in racing games post 2000), but everything produced is carefully concealed to look as American as possible to sell worldwide.

Globalism is the death of culture.

>>9614940
>it's a total red herring for videogames
OP was asking about British computers. British video games themselves are actually insanely successful.
>massively benefitted from the focus on service industries
Yes, but a good hardware industry could benefit video game sales as well, like what was happening in Japan. British video games were always the most technologically advanced in the world, but it took a while before they actually competed with Japanese and American games. Take ARM for example, a powerful and insanely popular CPU that was born in the UK, yet the Brits themselves couldn't manufacture a financially successful computer or console hardware for it. The Acorn Archimedes was a market failure because British manufacturing was expensive. Imagine if Brits captured the video game hardware market and managed to create an ARM console in the late 80s.

then comes the jumps, just jump, but, on the 2 and 3 jump you should steer left so you enter the zigzag (or easy left) with ur car in a 10 degree angle to the left

then comes another zig zag, just make a straight line

then comes that big right turn with the helicopter at the end, you should be riding on the grass (outter) part of the turn then steer right and try to touch the inside of the turn and then try to get out of the turn as close as possible to the inside, ur gonna jump, and you want to jump at a speed of at least 210kmh

finish

Adding to the PMD stuff that still counts as retro

Screech is fucked up. It works outside the standard buff/debuff formula, and no amount of Defense Curling will undo a Screech debuff. Having ultra high defense stats and getting hit by merely a single one can make you go from taking 1 damage from weak enemies to over 50. At 2 Screeches, you have roughly 3% of your normal defense stat, a stronger debuff than anything else in the game.
However, if you've got a pokemon that can use it alongside a multihit attack like Fury Swipes, you can combine the two so they come out in the same turn. You can simply delete anything in your path with this combo.

Sonicboom counts as well. Normally it only hits for 20 damage all the time, but for some reason it hits for 55 damage in Rescue Team. It is also a ranged attack and never misses. Simply put, if you have it in a challenge Level 1 dungeon, 99% of the dungeon dies in only 2 uses, and you never have to get close.

>>9611525
The official story is that only two bullets struck people in the motorcade. One bullet was the headshot on JFK (that one hit no one else). Before that, one bullet entered JFK's upper back, exited near his throat, and continued on to wound Connally who was sitting in front of him. Critics say that a single bullet could not have caused all of the non-fatal wounds to JFK and Connally and would have had to take a "magic" flight path to do so, changing directions more than once. The official story is that the critics are misrepresenting JFK and Connally's seating positions, and that yes a single bullet could cause all the wounds while traveling in a fairly straight line, or at least a path that's reasonable for a bullet to take after penetrating flesh and bone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9611591
There's a lot to it.

Oswald was using an Italian 6.5mm Carcano rifle. These have been maligned for poor accuracy, but a huge part of this is that Italian ammunition from the WW2 era was retardedly inconsistent and very seldom actually to spec, velocity and projectile weight could often vary a fair bit through what you were supplied, so it wasn't too rare for the zero of your rifle to plain not match the ammunition you were issued and firing, repeatedly shifting from one round to the next in the worst of cases.
Another is the exact caliber, it uses a 0.267 inch projectile, which isn't used by any other 6.5mm rifle cartridge, and isn't commonly available, as it's never been a very popular cartridge either, it's only ever received very tacit support, what little commercial ammunition which has been around is usually loaded with an undersized or oversized projectile. As the right caliber projectiles aren't even commonly manufactured, handloading for it isn't easy either, you would need to try to size down the oversized ones, or cast your own.
Thus, shooting surplus or commercial ammunition, you could often expect rather lackluster performance.

However, this doesn't mean that there was never adequate 6.5mm Carcano ammunition, WW1 era Italian ammunition maintained acceptable consistency, and this is what Italy fought with in Ethiopia, as forces there didn't want to rely on the later stuff. There was also American made ammunition which was loaded appropriately, Greece was relying on a number of Carcano rifles after WW2, and they had US made ammunition manufactured and sent to them (don't remember if this was military aid via the Department Of Defense, or the Greeks contracting the manufacturers on their own). This American made ammunition would eventually be surplused and some found itself in the US, and this was the ammunition which Oswald had.
posts.filename: Jim Gaffigan looks on in displeasure as Jim Belushi shoots Seth Meyers

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There's the idea that Oswald was a terrible marksman, which are untrue. His merit badges indicate that he was pretty decent with a rifle, so against a slow moving target under 100yds, a good rifleman shouldn't have any trouble making some hits, assuming the rifle was accurate enough.
Testing suggests that it was, a Carcano rifle in good condition and with suitable ammunition would fit the bill. There's some discrepancy regarding the scope, where there's signs of damage on the side of it, and a pair of shims needed to secure it tightly were absent, so it wouldn't necessarily have been as accurate in that state, but it's also not known if the rifle was like that during the shooting, or if this happened at some later point. Oswald couldn't make any testimony about it because he was killed, which is admittedly conveniently inconvenient.

The biggest point of contention is that the bullet couldn't have behaved like it did, or that the recovered projectile is fake.
More modern styles of bullets, the rounded pointed shape, referred to as 'spitzers', are quite prone to cavitation when penetrating flesh, ergo the same thing a propeller does as it cuts through water to drive a boat forward, except in an instant. This leads to a lot of tearing and distortion of tissue, larger wound channels, and the projectile is likely to fragment or deform, particularly if it hits bone, itself which will shatter, thus these kinds of wounds are quite intense and gruesome.
The world largely transitioned to this style of bullet for rifles right around WW1, but Italy did not, they stuck to an older style for 6.5mm Carcano, a cylindrical, roundnosed projectile of much greater weight. They're slower and retain more momentum, they deform a lot less, so when they yaw inside a person, they can make some pretty wacky and narrow curved wound channels, compared to later and more efficient bullets.

If you look at the recovered bullets, there is actually SOME deformation, contrary to common claims.

>>9613092
>>9613151
I should say that roundnosed bullets for rifles is still a thing, though typically as a softpoint for hunting, where you can produce expansion.
.30-30 Winchester is an example of an older rifle cartridge which just kind of stuck with roundnosed bullets, primarily out of a concern over magazine tube detonations in older lever-action rifles (which are honestly rather overstated), but likely also because the projectiles can be made slightly cheaper.
Even then though, you really would struggle to find actual round nosed, full metal jacket loads of .30-30 off the shelf today, the vast majority instead being some manner of soft point or/and flat nose, optionally so called 'Leverevolution' ammunition, where it's a soft point but with an added pointed tip made out of some vaguely soft-ish synthetic, as to let you get better aerodynamics and range, akin to spitzers but without the risk of magazine tube oopsies.

I will say it has a lot of "pizazz". It's one of those games where shooting enemies feels very satisfying. Everything has a good crunchy impact about it. A lot of the music, and sound design is very good. The presentation is all obviously very appealing if you're a James Bond fan. I like the gimmick of higher difficulties adding more mission objectives, and I wish that became more of a thing in video games.

Depends what you're looking for in a game, really. It's probably not the most high tier competitive shooter. It doesn't have the smoothest controls. They work, but they're of their time.

Do I like it a lot? Yes. Are a new generation about to be introduced to it, only to piss and moan because it's not Overwatch? Also yes.

You put all the arcade roms into
>C:\...\Mame\Roms\
Don't unzip the roms or change any filenames.

For roms of other platforms MAME emulates you have put them into another folder in the roms folder. For Atari 2600 games for example you have to put them to
>C:\...\Mame\Roms\a2600\
Again they all have to be zipped and with the right filenames.


The base romset for the arcade games is only like 72 GB. Only download the CHDs as needed as they close to a TB and only needed for few games.

He's trying to bring up the fact that many arcade games, especially older ones, were split across several or dozens of chips. These are all dumped separately. However, MAME has supported just putting these files into an archive for decades now if not since launch. Technically some console games do this too, NES games had at least two ROM chips for graphics and program data, they are just dumped into a single file. Nobody has exclusively distributed MAME ROMS or sets with the ROMS separate for ages now. Nowadays there are even merged sets which put different revisions of a game in a single archive.

>>9610407
There are three versions of the current MAME set. Split, Merged, and Un-Merged.
Split is every unique group of roms in it's own .zip file, meaning all games using the QSound HLE will just be looking for a qsound_hle.zip in your /roms directory. You'll need the Parent ROM, and whatever Clone ROM you want for that specific region/revision of the game. Merged is the BIOS files, parent, and all clones in the same .zip file, meaning all needed files to make the Parent work are present, and with some work you can get the Clones to work as well. Which is good if you aren't picky about the region/revision. Un-Merged is the parent and clones having their own .zip files that contain ALL needed files to work. There's a great deal of duplication because of this, but every single .zip file is stand-alone and you can be certain that one .zip will have everything you need.
Split is for people who want to be efficient and have everything, Merged is for people who want to have everything but have a cleaner directory with less .zip's. Un-Merged is for people who just want to play individual games and don't wanna be bothered with hunting down all the required BIOS or device files, and don't care if they lose a GB or two to duplicate files.
Why exactly are you downloading the Split set, freaking out over nothing working right, and downloading the ENTIRE fucking set to fix it? Why not just download the Un-Merged set?

posts.com:
Get you a stable remap going!
"What's the matter, boy? MAME forgot your buttons again? That sucks!" -"Tired of having to reconfigure your inputs all the time? You're about to lose it and ready to give up? Wait! There's yet hope."

Introducing:
By default MAME instantly resets any button configuration that is being loaded or currently in use if the specified controller is not connected or drops connection while the program is still being executed. Scenarios like this include a wireless controller going into sleep mode, a weak battery giving out during gameplay or a cable pulled too early. But there's a solution: Write your own remap file using a stable controller ID and MAME's devicemap feature today - MAME won't forget your buttons ever again!

How to:
1. Connect your controller of choice.
2. Go to Control Panel > Device Manager > Human Interface Devices > HID Conform Game Controller > Your Controller > Properties > Details > pick Hardware IDs from the drop down menu and note it down.
3. Write a text document like pic related to permanently map your buttons to player 1 using your controller's hardware ID*** (see 2nd post). Save as a cfg-file and name it a single word without any spaces or special characters.
4. Put the new cfg-file into a directory called 'ctrlr' inside your MAME program directory. Create it if it doesn't exist already.
5. Open mame.ini > Under section '# CORE SEARCH PATH OPTIONS' set 'ctrlrpath' to 'ctrlr'. Under section '# CORE INPUT OPTIONS' set 'ctrlr' to the name of your remap cfg-file. Leave out the file extension.
6. Delete 'default.cfg' in the 'cfg' directory of your MAME installation. Your remap is the new default now! This step might not be 100% necessary but it autogenerates a new one anyway if needed.
7. Done
posts.filename: Games - Arcade - MAME Stable Button Remap w. Hardware ID Guide

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9612510 Continued

Result:
MAME won't ever forget your buttons again. Doesn't matter if your controller loses connection, goes into sleep mode, the battery dies or you pull the cable too early. It's Plug-and-Play now and will be recognized 100% reliably by its hardware ID.

Advice:
If you are using an 8-button arcade stick the layout illustrated below is highly recommended as it is the most suited default across all machines, offering you the NeoGeo 4-button top row and 6-button layout a la Street Fighter at the same time.

1234
4567

Note that none of this prevents you from making further adjustments to input settings on a per game basis from inside the MAME GUI if necessary. MAME creates a config file for every game you boot inside the cfg directory and those have precedence over the default which we have redefined here.

Documentation
https://docs.mamedev.org/advanced/devicemap.html

***DISCLAIMER (see 1st post)
Controller button names and enumeration as well as hardware ID will vary. Figuring them out is up to the user. It is recommended to create a game specific remap including all physical buttons first and using that as reference. It will be located in the cfg directory.

Stop downloading Split sets if you don't know what the fuck you are doing and can't be bothered to figure it out. UnMerged sets were created specifically for everyone who just wants to play game. They literally have every file you need to make the game work in the .zip, unless it uses CHD's. CHD's aren't rocket science either. Make folder inside /roms directory with the same name as the .zip of the game, and put the .CHD files for that game inside of it. San Francisco Rush would need a folder called /sfrush, and the needed .CHD file(s) inside of it, and the sfrush.zip stays inside the base /roms folder. If using UnMerged sets, that's all you need to do.

Friendly reminder that the public pleasuredome torrents are up to date, complete, and available in all three formats. Split, Merged, and UnMerged. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9612604
Powering up the fire flower is a better idea than nerfing the feather. The feather's robust mechanics are what make Mario World what it is. But the fire flower's problem is that it's scaled to the challenges of Mario 1. As the games advanced and started throwing more shit at you the strength of the fire flower diminished. There are too many things immune to it. The fortresses are filled with thwomps, buzzsaws, etc. A fire flower only serves as an extra hit in there.

They seem to notice this though. Mario 3, Mario World, and Mario Land 2 all have the fire flower for posterity but the games put a much heavier emphasis on their own respective power ups and build the levels around that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9613186
Do not download full romsets.
Do not bother with fancy front-ends like Hyperspin.
RetroArch is probably going to be your best choice for 5th gen and earlier.
Pick out a game by browsing the internet, reading old magazines, or talking to people irl.
When you pick out a game download the instruction booklet for it and read it completely before ever starting up the game.
Print the booklet out if you wish and keep it as a memento.
Look up some ads, flyers, and commercials to get a sense of the game's marketing campaign.
Read retro reviews and previews of the game to get a feel for the atmosphere surrounding the game's release.
Use a good, comfortable controller and chair.
If possible play on a different set-up than your desktop PC.
Consider purchasing a new controller to coincide with a playthrough of a much-anticipated game to make it feel more special to you.
I don't recommend playing console games on a handheld but to each their own. If that is what is most comfortable for you then go for it.
Do the research to get your software configuration set-up for the game and go through the process of emu config methodically. Expect it to take an evening if you are going in blind. Read the emu documentation.
Set aside time mentally for gaming. Tell yourself this is not a "waste of time". Life isn't about trying to be productive every waking moment.
Eat some decent food before gaming, junk food makes you lethargic and perform worse in action games.
When you beat a game purchase a small keepsake related to the game to put on your shelf.

Tiger-Heli is probably the best beginner shmup there is as it forces you to learn all of the basics to complete it without dying, and also has very forgiving checkpoints. Ideally, you want to practice sections without dying though, as you can just brute-force through sections with dying.

It's just a very basic game that beginners would probably find too primitive/boring, and the main flaw is just that the terrain and enemies are so limited that it's hard to actually know/memorize which section you're at because it all flows together.

>>9590227
All depend on what you are looking for.

Any shmup can be your first it really, depend on the dedication you want to poor on it, even more true when nowdays you have training tools, adjustable auto fire,rewind and save states which make the training way more efficient and short.

Also be aware that some games can be average to hard to 1CC but very hard to insane 2ALL ( 2nd Loop), some Psikyo games are like this for example.

Now for the recommendation I try to give you some easily emulated or game available on steam or ACA :
Relatively easy.
Dariusburst AC : depend on the route but it mostly easy/mild hard at best for an 1CC)
Akai Katana got released last month it's a mild difficulty cave with a lot of thing to learn from.
Area 88 is fun arcade game you may learn movement and placement, learning curve is kind of flat but expect a small pick at level 5. give the snes/sfc version a try too.

Normal
R-type leo is kind of the same you may also learn some stuff about force and option (harder at level 4).
Fighting Hawk is close to Area 88 but as a verti. not too hard not too easy
Metal Black is between the 2 but you won't learn that much from as the game is weird AF.

Outzone depend on the version and weapon management can be a nice game to pick.

Also most Psikyo and Cave games 1CC can be put here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Battletoads.

Battletoads is not hard in the same way Ninja Gaiden, Zelda, or Castlevania are hard. No matter what you say about those games, their mechanics can be mastered. Even if it's really damned unlikely, it is still POSSIBLE to make it through even the most difficult sections on your first try, if your skills with the mechanics are honed. Battletoads is not like that. It is literally won through trial and error. Throughout the entire game, there is not one fucking action taken that a reasonable person would expect any player to make on a whim. Beating the game requires you to die multiple times. Period.

Yep, when I got a Game Boy Pocket on a family trip to Tenerife, I also got a multicart for it. It claimed to be 32 games in 1, but it was more like, 12 or even 8, and the games were just listed again with different titles. Apparently some multicarts actually feature modifiers or cheats for the game when you select the alternate titles, but as far as I could tell, this wasn't the case with mine or my brother's, and it was the exact same game.

I can't seem to find any pictures online of the one I had, and I still have that thing lying around somewhere, so I guess I should dig it out and take a picture of it just for reference's sake. I don't think these things have much value, but there's some niche collectors who collect these bootleg Game Boy carts because they're fun and usually very cheap, some of the more unusual ones don't even have a menu interface, instead they have pic related, a little button on the cartridge body which you press, rebooting the Game Boy and loading the next game in line.

Pocket-protected scientists built a wall of iron and crashed a Battletoads cart into it at 400 miles per hour, and the cart was unharmed. Sorry if this gets a bit away from OP's topic, but I was sent on a nostalgia spiral on the subject of those Game Boy multicarts. Let's see, going through my memory, I think me and my brother had these games on ours, some shared, some not:
>Tetris
>Dr. Mario
>Battle City (port of Famicom-only game)
>Snake (Serpent, ergo Snake but with some added gameplay depth compared to the classic ones, has very awkward controls though)
>Flipull
>Tom & Jerry (based on that not very good movie, I liked the cartoons way more)
>Super Mario Land
>"Super Mario 4" (actually a reskinned Crayon Shin-Shan game)
>Hercules (based on the Disney movie/cartoon, was kind of awkward and difficult to play, didn't enjoy it much)
>Alleyway (a good Breakout clone)
>Othello
>Bomb Jack
>Hugo (one of those Crazy Castle games, with that European cartoon troll I never quite liked)
>Motocross Maniacs
It ranged mostly from decent to very good, so combined with the number of titles, the value was through the roof, thank God for piracy! Tetris even worked with the link cable.

>>9609792
I saw mention of an Atari 2600 multi-game cartridge which actually WAS 128 in 1, but it was one of those button cartridges, ergo if you wanted to play the 128th game on the cartridge, it means you had to press that button to reboot and cycle through each game in order to get to the end, 127 times.
I'm glad that multicarts with a menu interface are more common, I'm not sure I would have played mine as much if I had to do that manual cycling shit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9613863
>>9612972
You have to put yourself in the mindset of the time.

In order to continue in arcade games you had to pay up. Then suddenly, console games are getting arcade ports at home (or games designed like other arcade games like Adventure Island) and devs wondered how you can make that fair.

For a while games tended to have hidden continue mechanics, AI isn't the only one, Rad Racer is another example from the same time period. After a while that disappeared in favour of non hidden continues, but very limited in numbers, before eventually infinite continues became a norm. These changes happened with mentalities in game design straying further away from arcade and closer to console.

Continues in AI and Rad Racer being hidden is simply because mentalities just did not think it was normal to have free infinite continues just yet, especially in regards to games that follow gameplay standards of arcade games

so yeah you can call that a cheat if you want, just don't forget the mindset of the time period when you think that. Had the same game been made a few years later, continues wouldn't be hidden, and that's exactly what happened with AI2 and 3 (the bee only helps to keep your items upon continuing)

posts.com:
>>9596872
>brightness is at about 50% now
That sounds like too much. I have my Trinitron at 3 ticks out of 24 or so, while keeping contrast around the middle of the scale. There is some really slight black crushing, but I get almost true blacks this way.
Remember that "brightness" is the black level setting, and "contrast" is the actual maximum brightness. This has been mislabeled for decades, confusing people to no end. Fortunately some manufacturers have started to change this naming convention to better reflect what those settings do, like LG with their last year OLED models.
Now, to do this adjustment properly you'll need to sit in a dark room and bring out a brightness test pattern of sorts, for example the color bars in the 240p Test Suite. Then you turn down the brightness all the way and make your way up until the bar nearest to black gets barely visible (is a bit brighter than black). Similarly for the contrast, you want to avoid near-white highlights getting blown out, so you should be able to differentiate the value that's nearest to white from pure white. Realistically, you'll probably have to settle on some sort of compromise between true blacks and a bit of black crush as no display is perfect. But hey, that ghosting should be gone at least.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9604227
240p is strictly speaking an implementation of 480i, with a caveat. 480p is nice at least in principle but it's a pretty narrow subset of displays that can do it and handle 240p input timings properly through the same input (Dreamcast and PS2 are the only consoles with both 240p and 480p games, and not a hell of a lot of the former discounting backwards compatibility, and Dreamcast has issues with games and/or resolution modes outright not supporting certain connectors itself, but still) I don't know a lot about the Dreamcast, but PS2 and Gamecube tend to lower color depth for 480p so it's not an absolute upgrade and probably depends on how your display handles each and your personal preference. On an LCD with bad deinterlacing 480p is going to shit on 480i obviously.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9608431
Felix the Cat for the NES has been an absolute delight for me to play. I'm currently playing it as I write this, and I can't stop smiling.

The game design and art style are remarkable; Felix looks great, with his iconic happy face, perfectly suited for a console made in the late 80s. He brings a lot of personality to the game and makes platforming easy but difficult enough to challenge my skills. Aside from the visuals, I find the music and sound design to be outstanding. The upbeat tunes always keep me engaged and keep me wanting to achieve the levels quicker.

What really stands out to me about this game is the level design. It really allows me to think outside of the box as I make my way through each stage. The levels are inventive, and their designs come with plenty of surprises and hazards that never fail to keep me on my toes. I get to experiment with different approaches and plan my movements carefully in order to succeed in each level. I love that some levels even have hidden features that reward exploration and experimentation.

On top of all of that, Felix the Cat for the NES is just plain enjoyable. Everything from the characters, enemies, and bosses to the gameplay, graphics, and level design all combine to form one positively fun experience. Whenever I feel like I've had enough of the game, I'm reminded of why I got it; it's just a joy to play and it never ceases to bring a smile to my face.

In the end, Felix the Cat for the NES is the perfect action platformer for me. It looks great, sounds great, and is extremely fun to play. I could not be more satisfied with it, and I can't wait to see what else it has to offer as I continue my adventure with it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I like The Adventures of Batman and Robin for the Genesis for how colorful, relentless and psychotic it is, that paired with my favorite usage of the Genesis sound chip seals the deal. Seriously, look up the song Psycho Section from that game, it's unbelievable how good that shit is, the mastery of timbre and changeups and the attention to detail on the soundtrack are just unparalleled on the console. Jesper Kyd fucking rules for doing that. There was no reason that the music for a Batman game on the Genesis had to be THAT incredible, but he was given a task and he put his entire being into it and I think that mentality is beautiful.

Also the game used almost every trick the Genesis had to offer to deliver the most visually compelling presentation they could, any excuse to add 3D feeling depth and dimension to things. Entire dev team of people who refused to half ass anything, that game deserves all the love in the world.

>>9613987
Much worse, we'd probably not even get half of those and if we did they'd be the downgraded "arcade" versions.

What had to happen, happened. Sega didn't capitalize on what made them good, their hardware was already underpowered for the time, their controller sucked, their games were expensive and geared towards a Japanese/arcade audience mostly (which to me isn't a bad thing at all, on the contrary, but to the average joe player it certainly is) but even the japs didn't want those games, everyone was fucking tired of arcade games at that point and the PS2 brought new stuff to the front. Thankfully Sega were a major component in making the Xbox successful.

To this day I'm surprised MS didn't outright buy Sega but maybe the Japs didn't want to sell or their finances were dodgy. Someone who watched one of those epic gaymen youtubers retelling "why the Dc failed" will probably correct me however.
